titlestmt.author: Compiled by Anne Rhodes

odd.head: General
odd.p: 1703 interviews as of January 10, 2022. OHAM regularly conducts new interviews to add to this collection. This finding aid describes both digitized and born digital interview recordings in this collection. For digitized interviews, Oral History of American Music also holds the original recordings, on a variety of legacy audio and video formats.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major Figures in American Music is the core unit of Oral History of American Music. It consists of over 1,7000 interviews with composers, performers, and other significant musicians. The first subjects were those most fragile in terms of age and health, such as Eubie Blake, Nadia Boulanger, Aaron Copland, Harry Partch, Charles Seeger, Claire Reis, and Virgil Thomson. Among other senior composers interviewed during the OHAM's first decade were John Cage, Lou Harrison, Ernst Krenek, Leo Ornstein, and William Schuman. As OHAM proceeded, composers actively involved in their careers were included and have been updated periodically. To name a few: John Adams, Anthony Braxton, David Del Tredici, Lukas Foss, David Lang, Steve Reich, and Julia Wolfe. OHAM's program also includes oral histories with emerging young talents, with the plan to track their careers as they unfold in the future. In addition to interviews with primary subjects, the core unit includes testimonies from secondary sources about George Gershwin, Henry Cowell, Harry Lawrence Freeman, Percy Grainger, and Arnold Schoenberg.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research. The finding aid includes links to stream most interviews online via Oral History of American Music's (OHAM) AV access system, Aviary. Yale users can login to Aviary using their Yale University ID, to stream these interviews without restriction. Other users are able to request access to interviews directly through Aviary. For detailed access instructions, see OHAM's website. Please sumbit a Transcript Request to inquire about the availability of a transcript.
This finding aid also includes links to Table of Contents for many interviews.
Some interviews may not have been digitized or are otherwise not available to stream online. However, some of these interviews may have transcripts available (see above).
Some interviews may be restricted. Access to these restricted interviews may only be granted to a patron who has first obtained direct permission from the interviewee or their estate.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Rights and permissions for Oral History of American Music materials vary between individual interviews. Researchers wishing to publish or broadcast Oral History of American Music materials are responsible for obtaining direct authorization from copyright holders: generally, the interviewees or their estates.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: OHV, Major Figures in American Music, Oral History of American Music, in the Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically by surname of interviewee.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: mp3, mp4, mp3, mpg, mov and mts files.

odd.head: Interviewer
odd.p: From material for film Ã¢â‚¬Å"I Have Nothing To Say and I Am Saying It.Ã¢â‚¬Â�?Beta tape is also labeled #26?Music Project for Television?This video contains mostly clips from older movies or TV interviews.?Brief shot of Cage and video editor sitting at machine--Excerpts from Ã¢â‚¬Å"Dreams That Money Can BuyÃ¢â‚¬Â� (1947): a surreal film accompanied by prepared piano music. The film involves spinning circular patterns and a shot of a woman in a costume descending a staircase. The film ends with a close-up shot of a man opening his eyes and a narrator saying something like Ã¢â‚¬Å"imagine a man having a dream like that. If he werenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t such an extrovert, he could have been a poet!Ã¢â‚¬Â� ?Black and white clip of an interview with a brother of an artist (one of the Duchamp brothers?) discussing the artistsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s work and the concept of taste.?Excerpt from film Ã¢â‚¬Å"The CollaboratorsÃ¢â‚¬Â� (Cage, Cunningham and Rauschenberg with David Vaughan (1987). An Interviewer with John Cage, Merce Cunningham, and a sculptor/designer who collaborated with Cage and Cunningham on Minutae and Antic Meet. The interview also has clips from performances of Minutae and Antic Meet and older black and white stills of Cage/Cunningham performances. The Interviewer and three men discuss: Minutae--the effect of collaboration between artists--effect of collaboration repeated--Antic Meet--evolution of CageÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s music--changing from use of instruments to use of electronics--the concept of Ã¢â‚¬Å"live electronicÃ¢â‚¬Â� music.???Photos from the making of the movie, postcards, and one portrait stored at OHAM??

odd.head: Interviewer
odd.p: From material for film Ã¢â‚¬Å"I Have Nothing To Say and I Am Saying It.Ã¢â‚¬Â??Beta tape is also labeled #32?Music Project for Television.?An unidentified man (some sort of art history expert?) sits in a room and answers questions from an unidentified male Interviewer.?DuchampÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s first involvement with Cage--Cage living at Peggy GuggenheimÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s--being thrown out of the GuggenheimÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s and first meeting Duchamp--Cage playing chess with Mrs. Duchamp--humor in DuchampÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s work--humor (often accidental) in CageÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s work--beginning of Cage-Cunningham collaboration at Cornish College--Cage and CunninghamÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s aesthetic of independence of music and dance--similarity of Cage and CunninghamÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s artistic approach of liberation from the self--CunninghamÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s background with Martha Graham and ballet--CageÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s transcendentalist background--CageÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s interest in Thoreau--4Ã¢â‚¬â„¢/33Ã¢â‚¬â„¢Ã¢â‚¬Â?and its relation to Rauschenberg--the audience as artist.???Photos from the making of the movie, postcards, and one portrait stored at OHAM??

odd.head: Interviewer
odd.p: Parts t and u have been removed from the access transcript at the request of JohnstonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s family. Audio files of these sections should be restricted from use as well. Family and the Interviewer noted that Johnston was tired and perhaps an unreliable narrator in this section. (However, the full transcript has been kept an may be made available to an appropriate researcher).???A hard copy of a version of the transcript that includes extensive annotations and opinions from transcriber Brek Renzleman is located in JohnstonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s composer file. This transcript is restricted and only available for in-person research. It is not to be reproduced and is not endorsed by OHAM.??Contacts regarding this intervew are re Jeff Gibbens (musical historian) and Michael Mitchell (JohnstonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s executor and personal representative). Contact information for both can be found in the OHAM directory.
